text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on June 9 in history:
1549 - The Church of England adopted The Book of Common Prayer, compiled by Thomas Cranmer.
1672 - Peter I of Russia, known as Peter the Great, born. He introduced western influence into Russia and founded St. Petersburg which he made the new capital.
1781 - George Stephenson, English locomotive designer, born. His Rocket was chosen as the first locomotive on the Liverpool-Manchester railway.
1800 - In Napoleon's Italian campaign, the first Battle of Montebello was fought and French forces defeated the Austrians.

1815 - The Congress of Vienna closed with the signing of the Final Act. Among its provisions, Belgium and Luxembourg united with Holland to form the Netherlands, Switzerland was neutral, East Poland ceded to Russia and its western provinces to Prussia. Changes also affected Italy, Spain and Portugal.
1836 - Elizabeth Garrett Anderson, British physician and the first woman to qualify as a doctor in England, born.
1870 - Charles Dickens, English novelist whose work includes "Great Expectations" and "David Copperfield", died.
1874 - Cochise, the Chiricahua Apache Indian chief, died. He was one of the leaders of Indian resistance to white settlers in the U.S. southwest.
1892 - Cole Porter, U.S. composer and lyricist whose many famous musicals include "Anything Goes", "Kiss Me Kate" and "Can Can".
1898 - An agreement was signed under which Hong Kong was leased to Britain from China for a period of 99 years.
1904 - The London Symphony Orchestra presented its inaugural concert.
1908 - King Edward VII of Britain met Tsar Nicholas II of Russia on board the Royal Yacht anchored in the Baltic. It was the first meeting between a Tsar and a British monarch.
1916 - Robert McNamara, American industrialist, defense secretary during the war in Vietnam, and president of the World Bank from 1968-81, born.
1918 - The Noyon-Montidier offensive, a drive by the German army in northern France to threaten Paris, began.
1928 - Charles Kingsford-Smith and Charles Ulm became the first to fly across the Pacific when they ended their flight from California to Brisbane.
1958 - Robert Donat, British actor of stage and screen and Oscar winner for his part in the film "Goodbye Mr Chips", died.
1959 - The first submarine with Polaris missiles, the USS George Washington, was launched by the U.S.
1964 - Lord Beaverbrook (William Maxwell Aitken) Canadian-born media magnate, died.
1975 - The first live broadcast from the British House of Commons took place.
1976 - Dame Sybil Thorndike, distinguished British actress of stage and screen. died.
1991 - Mount Pinatubo, a Philippines volcano that had been dormant for 600 years, erupted, causing the evacuation of U.S. troops from their air base.
1992 - More than 700 known Mafiosi were arrested in a new crackdown in southern Italy.
1993 - U.S. officials admitted veterans of the Gulf War were suffering from a mystery illness.
